children.value: In this chapter, we extend our description of rotational dynamics to include the rotational equivalents of kinetic energy and momentum. We also develop the framework for describing the motion of rolling objects. We will see that many of the relations that hold for linear quantities also hold for angular quantities.
Understand how to define the rotational kinetic energy of an object as well as its total kinetic energy.
Understand how to model rolling motion, and what slipping means in the context of rolling motion.
Understand how to define the angular momentum of an object and when it is conserved.
How can you model the motion of a downwards going yo-yo?
It is similar to that of an object falling with a force of drag.
It is similar to that of an object rolling down an incline.
It is similar to that of an object sliding down an incline.
It is similar to that of an object rotating about a fixed axis of rotation.
Rotational kinetic energy of an object

children.label: Rotational kinetic energy of an object

children.value: In this section, we show how to define the rotational kinetic energy of an object that is rotating about a stationary axis in an inertial frame of reference. Consider a solid object that is rotating about an axis with angular velocity,

children.html: ω⃗\vec\omegaω

children.alt: An object rotating about an axis that is perpendicular to the page.

children.value: An object rotating about an axis that is perpendicular to the page.
We can model the object as being composed of many point particles, each with a mass

children.value: , since all particles are moving in circles centred about the axis of rotation.  We can thus write the total rotational kinetic energy of the object using the angular speed:

children.html: Krot=∑i12mivi2=∑i12miri2ω2=12ω2∑imiri2=12Iω2\begin{align*} K_{rot} &= \sum_i \frac{1}{2}m_iv_i^2 = \sum_i \frac{1}{2}m_ir_i^2\omega^2= \frac{1}{2} \omega^2 \sum_i m_ir_i^2\\ &=\frac{1}{2}I\omega^2 \end{align*}Krot​​=i∑​21​mi​vi2​=i∑​21​mi​ri2​ω2=21​ω2i∑​mi​ri2​=21​Iω2​

children.value: . We then recognized that the remaining sum is simply the definition of the object’s moment of inertia about the axis:

children.html: I=∑imri2\begin{align*} I = \sum_i mr_i^2 \end{align*}I=i∑​mri2​​

children.value: Thus, the rotational kinetic energy of an object rotating with angular speed
about an axis that is stationary in an inertial frame of reference is given by:

children.html: Krot=12Iω2\begin{align} \boxed{K_{rot}=\frac{1}{2}I\omega^2} \end{align}Krot​=21​Iω2​​​
III

children.value: is the object’s moment of inertia about that axis. The rotational kinetic energy is functionally very similar to the linear kinetic energy; instead of mass, we use the moment of inertia, and instead of speed squared, we use angular speed squared.
We can calculate the work done by a force exerted on an object rotating about a stationary axis in an inertial frame of reference. Let

children.html: F⃗\vec FF

children.value: be a force exerted at position,

children.html: r⃗\vec rr

children.value: , relative to the axis of rotation at some instant in time, and let the force be exerted in the plane perpendicular to the axis of rotation, as illustrated in

. Because the object is rotating about the given axis, only the component of the force that is tangent to the circle about which the point where the force is exerted can do work (only the component of the force that is parallel to the displacement can do work).
The work done by the force as the object rotates by a certain angle is given by:

children.html: W=∫F⃗⋅dl⃗=∫F⊥dl\begin{align*} W = \int \vec F \cdot d\vec l = \int F_\perp dl \end{align*}W=∫F⋅dl=∫F⊥​dl​
dl⃗d\vec ldl

F⃗\vec FF

children.html: r⃗\vec rr

children.value: , from the axis of rotation to the location where the force is exerted (

children.html: F⊥F_\perpF⊥​
F⃗\vec FF

children.value: that is tangent to the circle).

children.value: We can re-arrange this using Newton’s Second Law for rotational dynamics:

children.html: τ⃗net=Iα⃗=Idω⃗dt=Idωdθdθ⃗dt=Idωdθω⃗\begin{align*} \vec\tau_{net} &= I \vec\alpha\\ &= I \frac{d\vec\omega}{dt} = I \frac{d\omega}{d\theta}\frac{d\vec\theta}{dt}=I \frac{d\omega}{d\theta} \vec\omega \end{align*}τnet​​=Iα=Idtdω​=Idθdω​dtdθ​=Idθdω​ω​

children.value: which allows us to write the integral over a change in angular velocity instead of angular displacement:

children.html: Wnet=∫θ1θ2τ⃗net⋅dθ⃗=∫θ1θ2Idωdθω⃗⋅dθ⃗=∫ω1ω2Iωdω=12Iω22−12Iω12\begin{align*} W^{net} &= \int_{\theta_1}^{\theta_2}\vec\tau_{net}\cdot d\vec \theta = \int_{\theta_1}^{\theta_2}I \frac{d\omega}{d\theta} \vec\omega \cdot d\vec \theta\\ &=\int_{\omega_1}^{\omega_2}I \omega d\omega = \frac{1}{2}I\omega_2^2 - \frac{1}{2}I\omega_1^2 \end{align*}Wnet​=∫θ1​θ2​​τnet​⋅dθ=∫θ1​θ2​​Idθdω​ω⋅dθ=∫ω1​ω2​​Iωdω=21​Iω22​−21​Iω12​​

Total kinetic energy of an object

children.label: Total kinetic energy of an object

children.value: In the frame of reference of the centre of mass, an object rotating about an axis through its centre of mass with angular velocity,

children.html: ω⃗\vec \omegaω
KrotK_{rot}Krot​
Krot=12ICMω2\begin{align*} K_{rot}=\frac{1}{2}I_{CM}\omega^2 \end{align*}Krot​=21​ICM​ω2​
ICMI_{CM}ICM​

children.value: is the moment of inertia of the object about the axis through its centre of mass.
We wish to determine the kinetic energy of the object in an inertial frame of reference where the object’s centre of mass is moving with a velocity

children.html: v⃗cm\vec v_{cm}vcm​

children.value: ; that is, in a frame where the axis of rotation is moving with the velocity of the centre of mass. We model the object as being composed of particles of mass,

children.html: mim_imi​
r⃗i\vec r_iri​

children.value: , relative to the axis of rotation through the centre of mass. The velocity,

children.html: v⃗i\vec v_ivi​
iii

children.value: , in this frame of reference, is given by:

children.html: v⃗i=ω⃗×r⃗i+v⃗CM\begin{align*} \vec v_i = \vec\omega \times \vec r_i + \vec v_{CM} \end{align*}vi​=ω×ri​+vCM​​
ω⃗×r⃗i\vec\omega \times \vec r_iω×ri​

children.value: is the velocity of the particle as seen in the centre of mass (due to rotation). The kinetic energy of particle

children.html: iii
KiK_iKi​
Ki=12mivi2=12mi(v⃗i⋅v⃗i)\begin{align*} K_i = \frac{1}{2}m_iv_i^2 = \frac{1}{2}m_i(\vec v_i\cdot \vec v_i) \end{align*}Ki​=21​mi​vi2​=21​mi​(vi​⋅vi​)​

children.value: where we expressed the speed of the particle squared using a scalar product of the velocity of the particle with itself. The total kinetic energy of the object is found by summing the kinetic energies of all of the particles:

\begin{align*}
K_{tot} &= \sum \frac{1}{2}m_i(\vec v_i\cdot \vec v_i) \\
&=\frac{1}{2} \sum_i m_i (\vec\omega \times \vec r_i + \vec v_{CM}) \cdot (\vec\omega \times \vec r_i + \vec v_{CM})\\
&=\frac{1}{2} \sum_i m_i (\vec\omega \times \vec r_i)\cdot(\vec\omega \times \vec r_i ) + \frac{1}{2} \sum_i m_i (\vec v_{CM}) \cdot (\vec v_{CM}) + \sum_i m_i (\vec\omega \times \vec r_i) \cdot (\vec v_{CM})\\
&=\frac{1}{2}  \sum_i m_i \omega^2r_i^2 + \frac{1}{2} \sum_i m_i v_{CM}^2 + \sum_i m_i (\vec\omega \times \vec r_i) \cdot (\vec v_{CM})\\
&=\frac{1}{2} I_{CM}\omega ^2 + \frac{1}{2}M v_{CM}^2+\sum_i m_i (\vec\omega \times \vec r_i) \cdot (\vec v_{CM})
\end{align*}
children.html: Ktot=∑12mi(v⃗i⋅v⃗i)=12∑imi(ω⃗×r⃗i+v⃗CM)⋅(ω⃗×r⃗i+v⃗CM)=12∑imi(ω⃗×r⃗i)⋅(ω⃗×r⃗i)+12∑imi(v⃗CM)⋅(v⃗CM)+∑imi(ω⃗×r⃗i)⋅(v⃗CM)=12∑imiω2ri2+12∑imivCM2+∑imi(ω⃗×r⃗i)⋅(v⃗CM)=12ICMω2+12MvCM2+∑imi(ω⃗×r⃗i)⋅(v⃗CM)\begin{align*} K_{tot} &= \sum \frac{1}{2}m_i(\vec v_i\cdot \vec v_i) \\ &=\frac{1}{2} \sum_i m_i (\vec\omega \times \vec r_i + \vec v_{CM}) \cdot (\vec\omega \times \vec r_i + \vec v_{CM})\\ &=\frac{1}{2} \sum_i m_i (\vec\omega \times \vec r_i)\cdot(\vec\omega \times \vec r_i ) + \frac{1}{2} \sum_i m_i (\vec v_{CM}) \cdot (\vec v_{CM}) + \sum_i m_i (\vec\omega \times \vec r_i) \cdot (\vec v_{CM})\\ &=\frac{1}{2} \sum_i m_i \omega^2r_i^2 + \frac{1}{2} \sum_i m_i v_{CM}^2 + \sum_i m_i (\vec\omega \times \vec r_i) \cdot (\vec v_{CM})\\ &=\frac{1}{2} I_{CM}\omega ^2 + \frac{1}{2}M v_{CM}^2+\sum_i m_i (\vec\omega \times \vec r_i) \cdot (\vec v_{CM}) \end{align*}Ktot​​=∑21​mi​(vi​⋅vi​)=21​i∑​mi​(ω×ri​+vCM​)⋅(ω×ri​+vCM​)=21​i∑​mi​(ω×ri​)⋅(ω×ri​)+21​i∑​mi​(vCM​)⋅(vCM​)+i∑​mi​(ω×ri​)⋅(vCM​)=21​i∑​mi​ω2ri2​+21​i∑​mi​vCM2​+i∑​mi​(ω×ri​)⋅(vCM​)=21​ICM​ω2+21​MvCM2​+i∑​mi​(ω×ri​)⋅(vCM​)​

children.value: where the first term is the rotational kinetic energy that we found earlier. The second term, called the
, can be thought of as the kinetic energy of the whole system with mass

children.html: M=∑miM=\sum m_iM=∑mi​

children.value: , due to the translational motion of the centre of mass. The last term is identically zero; we can re-order the scalar product and factor

children.html: v⃗CM\vec v_{CM}vCM​

∑imi(ω⃗×r⃗i)⋅(v⃗CM)=(v⃗CM)⋅∑imi(ω⃗×r⃗i)=(v⃗CM)⋅∑imiv⃗i′\begin{align*} \sum_i m_i (\vec\omega \times \vec r_i) \cdot (\vec v_{CM}) &= (\vec v_{CM}) \cdot \sum_i m_i (\vec\omega \times \vec r_i)\\ &=(\vec v_{CM}) \cdot \sum_i m_i \vec v'_{i} \end{align*}i∑​mi​(ω×ri​)⋅(vCM​)​=(vCM​)⋅i∑​mi​(ω×ri​)=(vCM​)⋅i∑​mi​vi′​​
vi′=ω⃗×r⃗iv'_{i} = \vec\omega \times \vec r_ivi′​=ω×ri​
iii

children.value: in the center of mass frame of reference. But the sum:

children.html: ∑imiv⃗i′\begin{align*} \sum_i m_i \vec v'_{i} \end{align*}i∑​mi​vi′​​

children.value: is the numerator for the definition of the velocity of the centre of mass, which, in the centre of mass frame of reference is identically zero!
Thus, the total kinetic energy of an object of mass,

children.html: MMM

children.value: , that is rotating about an axis through its centre of mass with angular velocity,
, and whose centre of mass is moving with velocity,

children.html: v⃗CM\vec v_{CM}vCM​
Ktot=Krot+Ktrans=12ICMω2+12MvCM2\begin{align} \boxed{K_{tot}=K_{rot}+K_{trans}=\frac{1}{2} I_{CM}\omega ^2 + \frac{1}{2}M v_{CM}^2} \end{align}Ktot​=Krot​+Ktrans​=21​ICM​ω2+21​MvCM2​​​​

children.value: The total kinetic energy can be thought of as the sum of the rotational and kinetic energies.
In this section, we examine how to model the motion of an object that is rolling along a surface, such as the motion of a bicycle wheel. Consider the motion of a wheel of radius,

children.html: RRR
ω⃗\vec\omegaω

children.value: , about an axis perpendicular to the wheel and through its centre of mass,
as observed in the centre of mass frame

children.alt: A wheel rotating with angular velocity $\vec\omega$ about an axis through its centre of mass.

children.value: A wheel rotating with angular velocity

children.html: ω⃗\vec\omegaω

children.value: about an axis through its centre of mass.
In the frame of reference of the centre of mass, each point on the edge of the wheel has a velocity,

children.html: v⃗rot\vec v_{rot}vrot​
v⃗rot=ω⃗×r⃗\begin{align*} \vec v_{rot} = \vec \omega\times \vec r \end{align*}vrot​=ω×r​
r⃗\vec rr
RRR

children.value: ) from the centre of mass to the corresponding point on the edge of the wheel (shown in
for a point on the lower left of the wheel). The vector

ω⃗\vec \omegaω

children.value: , so that the speed of all points on the edge, as measured in the frame of reference of the centre of mass, is the same:

children.label: eq:angularmomentumrolling:vrot
children.html: vrot=ωR\begin{align} v_{rot} = \omega R \end{align}vrot​=ωR​​

children.value: Now, suppose that the whole wheel is moving, as it rolls on the ground, such that the centre of mass of the wheel moves with a velocity,

children.html: v⃗CM\vec{v}_{CM}vCM​

children.alt: A wheel rolling without slipping on the ground, with the centre of mass moving with velocity $\vec{v}_{CM}$. The wheel is shown at different instants in time, as the point shown in red moves around the centre of mass

children.value: A wheel rolling without slipping on the ground, with the centre of mass moving with velocity

children.html: v⃗CM\vec{v}_{CM}vCM​

children.value: . The wheel is shown at different instants in time, as the point shown in red moves around the centre of mass.
In the frame of reference of the ground, each point on the edge of the wheel will have a velocity

children.html: v⃗\vec vv
v⃗=v⃗rot+v⃗CM\begin{align*} \vec v = \vec v_{rot} + \vec v_{CM} \end{align*}v=vrot​+vCM​​

children.value: That is, in the frame reference of the ground, each point will have a velocity obtained by (vectorially) adding its velocity relative to the centre of mass,

children.html: v⃗rot\vec v_{rot}vrot​

children.value: , and the velocity of the centre of mass relative to the ground,

children.html: v⃗CM\vec v_{CM}vCM​

children.value: for one specific point, shown in red. The red vector corresponds to the velocity of the red point as the wheel rotates, and is obtained by adding the velocity of the centre of mass,

children.html: v⃗CM\vec v_{CM}vCM​
v⃗rot\vec v_{rot}vrot​

children.value: , relative to the centre of mass (shown as the dashed vector, tangent to the edge of the wheel).
Consider, specifically, the instant in time when the red point is at the bottom of the wheel, where the wheel makes contact with the ground.
If the wheel is not slipping with respect to the ground
, then the point is, at that instant, at rest relative to the ground. We call this type of motion
; the point on the rotating object that is in contact with the ground is instantaneously at rest relative to the ground. This is the scenario illustrated in
For the point in contact with the ground, the vectors

children.html: v⃗rot\vec v_{rot}vrot​
v⃗CM\vec v_{CM}vCM​

children.value: are anti-parallel, horizontal, and must sum to zero. Writing out the horizontal component of the velocity of that point (choosing the positive direction to be in the direction of the velocity of the centre of mass):

children.html: v=−vrot+vCM=0∴vrot=vCM\begin{align*} v &= -v_{rot} + v_{CM} = 0\\ \therefore v_{rot} &= v_{CM} \end{align*}v∴vrot​​=−vrot​+vCM​=0=vCM​​

children.value: and we find that, for rolling without slipping, the speed due to rotation about the centre of mass has to be equal to the speed of the centre of mass. The speed due to rotation about the centre of mass can be expressed using the angular velocity of the wheel about the centre of mass (Equation \ref{eq:angularmomentumrolling:vrot}). For rolling without slipping, we thus have the following relationship between angular velocity and the speed of the centre of mass:

children.message: Expected '}', got '&' at position 31: …boxed{\omega R &̲= v_{CM}}\quad …

children.value: It makes sense for the angular velocity to be related to the speed of the centre of mass. The faster the wheel rotates, the faster the centre of mass will move. If the wheel is slipping with respect to the ground, then the point of contact is no longer stationary relative to the ground, and there is no relation between the angular velocity and the speed of the centre of mass. For rolling with slipping, imagine the motion of your bicycle wheel as you try to ride your bike on a slick sheet of ice.
For rolling without slipping, the magnitude of the linear acceleration of the centre of mass,

children.html: aCMa_{CM}aCM​

children.value: , is similarly related to the magnitude of the angular acceleration of the wheel,

children.html: aCM=dvCMdt=ddtωR=Rdωdt∴aCM=Rα\begin{align*} a_{CM} &= \frac{dv_{CM}}{dt} = \frac{d}{dt}\omega R = R \frac{d\omega}{dt}\\ \therefore a_{CM} &= R\alpha \end{align*}aCM​∴aCM​​=dtdvCM​​=dtd​ωR=Rdtdω​=Rα​

children.value: ), the speed of the point on the wheel that is in contact with the ground is 0. What is the speed of the point at the top of the wheel?}

2vCM2v_{CM}2vCM​
ω⃗\vec \omegaω

children.value: , about the instantaneous axis of rotation is the same as when we model the motion as translation plus rotation about the centre of mass ,as in the previous section. Indeed, relative to the instantaneous axis of rotation, the centre of mass must still have a velocity

v⃗CM=ω⃗×r⃗CM∴vCM=ωR\begin{align*} \vec v_{CM} &= \vec\omega \times \vec r_{CM}\\ \therefore v_{CM} &= \omega R \end{align*}vCM​∴vCM​​=ω×rCM​=ωR​
r⃗CM\vec r_{CM}rCM​

children.value: is the vector from the axis of rotation to the centre of mass. This is the same condition for rolling without slipping that we found before. Similarly, the velocity of any point on the wheel, relative to the ground, is given by:

children.html: v⃗=ω⃗×r⃗\begin{align*} \vec v = \vec\omega \times \vec r \end{align*}v=ω×r​

for the point on the right side of the wheel). In particular, the velocity vector (in red) for any point is always perpendicular to the vector

children.value: for that point, which was not necessarily obvious when modelling the motion as rotation plus translation, as in

with respect to the horizontal, as shown in
. What is the angular acceleration of the disk, about an axis through its centre of mass, as it rolls without slipping down the slope?
In order to determine the angular acceleration of the disk about the centre of mass, we need to model the forces that are exerted on the disk. The forces exerted on the disk are:

children.html: F⃗g\vec F_gFg​

children.value: , the weight of the disk, exerted downwards at the centre of mass, with magnitude

children.html: MgMgMg
N⃗\vec NN

children.value: , a normal force perpendicular to the incline, exerted by the incline at the point of contact with the disk.

children.html: f⃗s\vec f_sf​s​

children.value: , a force of static friction parallel to the incline, exerted by the incline at the point of contact with the disk. Without this force, the disk would simply slide down the incline without rotating.
, along with the acceleration of the centre of mass, and our choice of coordinate system (we choose the

children.html: xxx

children.value: axis parallel to the acceleration of the centre of mass, to facilitate applying Newton’s Second Law).

children.alt: The forces on the disk rolling without slipping down an incline.

children.value: The forces on the disk rolling without slipping down an incline.
The angular acceleration of the disk about the centre of mass,

children.html: α⃗\vec \alphaα

children.value: is given by Newton’s Second Law for rotational dynamics:

children.html: τ⃗ext=ICMα⃗\begin{align*} \vec\tau_{ext} = I_{CM}\vec\alpha \end{align*}τext​=ICM​α​
τ⃗ext\vec\tau_{ext}τext​

children.value: is the net external torque on the disk about the centre of mass (which will be in the negative

children.html: zzz

children.value: The only force that can exert a torque about the centre of mass is the force of static friction. Gravity has a lever arm of zero and the normal force is anti-parallel to the vector that goes from the centre of mass to the point where the force is exerted. The net torque about the centre of mass is thus:

children.html: τ⃗ext=τ⃗fs=r⃗fs×f⃗s=−Rfsz^\begin{align*} \vec\tau_{ext} = \vec \tau_{f_s} = \vec r_{f_s}\times \vec f_s= -Rf_s\hat z \end{align*}τext​=τfs​​=rfs​​×f​s​=−Rfs​z^​

children.value: The angular acceleration will thus be in the negative

children.html: zzz

children.value: direction, and the magnitude is given by:

children.html: α=τextICM=Rfs12MR2=2fsMR\begin{align*} \alpha = \frac{\tau_{ext}}{I_{CM}}=\frac{Rf_s}{\frac{1}{2}MR^2}=\frac{2f_s}{MR} \end{align*}α=ICM​τext​​=21​MR2Rfs​​=MR2fs​​​

children.value: However, we do not know the magnitude of the force of static friction. We can use the

children.html: xxx
yyy

children.value: components of Newton’s Second Law to determine it (with acceleration of the centre of mass in the

children.html: xxx
∑Fx=Fgsin⁡θ−fs=MaCM∑Fy=N−Fgcos⁡θ=0\begin{align*} \sum F_x &= F_g\sin\theta - f_s = Ma_{CM}\\ \sum F_y &= N - F_g\cos\theta = 0 \end{align*}∑Fx​∑Fy​​=Fg​sinθ−fs​=MaCM​=N−Fg​cosθ=0​

children.value: Because the disk is rolling without slipping, the acceleration of the centre of mass is related to the angular acceleration of the disk:

children.html: acm=αR\begin{align*} a_{cm} = \alpha R \end{align*}acm​=αR​
xxx

children.value: component of Newton’s Second Law can thus be used to determine the magnitude of the force of static friction in terms of the angular acceleration:

children.html: Mgsin⁡θ−fs=MαR∴fs=Mgsin⁡θ−MαR\begin{align*} Mg\sin\theta - f_s &= M \alpha R\\ \therefore f_s &= Mg\sin\theta - M\alpha R \end{align*}Mgsinθ−fs​∴fs​​=MαR=Mgsinθ−MαR​

children.value: We can then substitute out the force of friction from our previous formula for the angular acceleration:

children.html: α=2fsMR=2Mgsin⁡θ−2MαRMR=2gsin⁡θR−2α∴α=2gsin⁡θ3R\begin{align*} \alpha &= \frac{2f_s}{MR}\\ &=\frac{2Mg\sin\theta - 2M\alpha R}{MR} = \frac{2g\sin\theta}{R} - 2\alpha \\ \therefore \alpha &= \frac{2g\sin\theta}{3R} \end{align*}α∴α​=MR2fs​​=MR2Mgsinθ−2MαR​=R2gsinθ​−2α=3R2gsinθ​​

children.value: Instead of modelling the motion of the disk  as rotation about the centre of mass and translation of the center of mass, we can also model it about the instantaneous axis of rotation.

The angular acceleration about the instantaneous axis of rotation will be the same as the angular acceleration about the centre of mass. About the instantaneous axis of rotation, only the force of gravity can exert a torque, since the normal force and the force of friction both have a lever arm of zero. The torque from the force of gravity, about the instantaneous axis of rotation is:

children.html: τ⃗g=−FgRsin⁡θz^=−MgRsin⁡θz^\begin{align*} \vec \tau_g = -F_gR\sin\theta \hat z = -MgR\sin\theta \hat z \end{align*}τg​=−Fg​Rsinθz^=−MgRsinθz^​

children.value: The torque from the force of gravity is equal to the moment of inertia of the disk about the instantaneous axis of rotation,

children.html: III
τext=τg=Iα∴α=τgI=MgRsin⁡θI\begin{align*} \tau ^{ext} = \tau_g &= I\alpha\\ \therefore \alpha &= \frac{\tau_g}{I} = \frac{MgR\sin\theta}{I} \end{align*}τext=τg​∴α​=Iα=Iτg​​=IMgRsinθ​​

children.value: The moment of inertia about the instantaneous axis of rotation is easily found using the parallel axis theorem:

children.html: I=ICM+MR2=12MR2+MR2=32MR2\begin{align*} I = I_{CM}+MR^2 = \frac{1}{2}MR^2 + MR^2 =\frac{3}{2}MR^2 \end{align*}I=ICM​+MR2=21​MR2+MR2=23​MR2​

children.value: This allows us to find the angular acceleration of the disk:

children.html: α=MgRsin⁡θI=MgRsin⁡θ32MR2=2gsin⁡θ3R\begin{align*} \alpha &= \frac{MgR\sin\theta}{I} = \frac{MgR\sin\theta}{\frac{3}{2}MR^2}\\ &=\frac{2g\sin\theta}{3R} \end{align*}α​=IMgRsinθ​=23​MR2MgRsinθ​=3R2gsinθ​​

children.value: as we found previously, but in this case, we did not need to use Newton’s Second Law to determine the force of friction.

We saw that we can model the dynamics of the rolling body using either an axis through the centre of mass, or an axis through the instantaneous axis of rotation. The latter was easier in this case, because it did not require using Newton’s Second Law.

By using an axis through the centre of mass to model the motion of the disk, it was clear that the force of static friction is required in order for the disk to rotate. Without the force of static friction, the disk would slide along the surface of the incline. The disk could still rotate if there is a force of kinetic friction that causes a torque that rotates the disk. If the surface were completely frictionless, the disk would simply slide down the incline, and we could model it as a sliding block. If the incline is too steep the force of static friction is no longer sufficient to provide the necessary torque required for the angular acceleration to be that which corresponds to rolling without slipping, and the disk would slip.
In this section, we show that we can define a quantity called
as the rotational equivalent of the linear momentum.
The angular momentum relative to a point of rotation,

children.html: L⃗\vec LL

children.value: , of a particle with linear momentum,

children.html: p⃗\vec pp​
L⃗=r⃗×p⃗\begin{align} \boxed{\vec L = \vec r\times \vec p} \end{align}L=r×p​​​​
r⃗\vec rr

children.value: is the vector from the point of rotation to the particle, and the linear momentum,

children.html: p⃗\vec pp​

children.value: , is defined relative to an inertial frame of reference in which the point of rotation is at rest.
Consider the time-derivative of angular momentum (where we have to use the product rule for derivatives):

children.html: dL⃗dt=ddt(r⃗×p⃗)=dr⃗dt×p⃗+r⃗×dp⃗dt=v⃗×p⃗+r⃗×dp⃗dt\begin{align*} \frac{d\vec L}{dt} &= \frac{d}{dt} (\vec r\times \vec p)\\ &=\frac{d\vec r}{dt}\times \vec p + \vec r\times\frac{d\vec p}{dt}\\ &=\vec v\times \vec p + \vec r\times\frac{d\vec p}{dt}\\ \end{align*}dtdL​​=dtd​(r×p​)=dtdr​×p​+r×dtdp​​=v×p​+r×dtdp​​​

children.value: The first term is zero, since

children.html: v⃗\vec vv
p⃗\vec pp​

children.value: by definition. Recall Newton’s Second Law written using linear momentum:

children.html: dp⃗dt=F⃗net\begin{align*} \frac{d\vec p}{dt} = \vec F^{net} \end{align*}dtdp​​=Fnet​
F⃗net\vec F^{net}Fnet

children.value: is the net force on the particle relative to the point of rotation. The rate of change of angular momentum is thus given by:

children.html: dL⃗dt=r⃗×dp⃗dt=r⃗×F⃗net\begin{align*} \frac{d\vec L }{dt} &= \vec r\times\frac{d\vec p}{dt}\\ &=\vec r\times\vec F^{net} \end{align*}dtdL​​=r×dtdp​​=r×Fnet​

children.value: where the term on the right is the net torque on the particle. Thus, the rate of change of angular momentum is given by:

children.html: dL⃗dt=τ⃗net\begin{align} \boxed{\frac{d\vec L}{dt} = \vec \tau_{net}} \end{align}dtdL​=τnet​​​​

children.value: which is analogous to the linear case, but we used angular momentum instead of linear momentum and net torque instead of net force. The net torque on a particle is thus equal to the rate of change of its angular momentum. In particular, the angular momentum of a particle will remain constant (not change with time) if the net torque on the particle is zero.
We can also define the angular momentum of a particle using only angular quantities:

children.html: L⃗=r⃗×p⃗=mr⃗×v⃗=mr2ω⃗\begin{align*} \vec L = \vec r \times \vec p = m \vec r \times \vec v = mr^2 \vec\omega \end{align*}L=r×p​=mr×v=mr2ω​
mmm

children.value: out of the momentum and used the definition

children.html: ω⃗=1/r2(r⃗×v⃗)\vec \omega = 1/r^2(\vec r \times \vec v)ω=1/r2(r×v)
mr2mr^2mr2
III

children.label: eq:angularmomentumrolling:liw
children.html: L⃗=mr2ω⃗=Iω⃗\begin{align} \boxed{\vec L = mr^2 \vec\omega = I \vec\omega} \end{align}L=mr2ω=Iω​​​

children.value: which is a close analogue to the definition of linear momentum, but we use moment of inertia instead of mass and angular velocity instead of velocity.

The angular momentum is thus parallel to the angular velocity of the particle about the point of rotation. If no net torque is exerted on the particle about that point, then the particle’s angular momentum about that point will remain constant. We can also consider the torque and angular momentum about an axis instead of a point; in that case, we would simply take the components of torque and angular momentum that are parallel to that axis.

\vspace{-0.35cm}

You then try to lift your right hand while lowering your left hand in order to tilt the rotation axis, as shown in the right panel. In doing so, you change the direction of the angular momentum (and angular velocity) of the wheel such that the angular momentum,

children.html: L⃗′\vec L'L′
ΔL⃗\Delta \vec LΔL

children.value: , as shown. The torque that is required in order to change the angular momentum is given by:

children.html: τ⃗=dL⃗dt∼ΔL⃗Δt\begin{align*} \vec \tau = \frac{d\vec L}{dt} \sim \frac{\Delta \vec L}{\Delta t} \end{align*}τ=dtdL​∼ΔtΔL​​
Δt\Delta tΔt

children.value: is the time that it takes to change the axis of rotation. The torque required in order to change the axis of rotation is directed in the same direction as

children.html: ΔL⃗\Delta \vec LΔL
yyy

children.value: direction). That is, you will not be able to simply tilt the axle as shown; if you want to tilt the axle, you will also need to push forward with you right hand and pull backwards with your left hand to exert the required torque (shown in the bottom right of the figure)! If you simply try to tilt the rotation axis, your right hand will be pushed towards you and your left hand away from you, as a reaction to the torque that would otherwise be required to tilt the axis!
In the previous section, we saw that the net external torque that is exerted on an object (or system) is equal to the rate of change of its angular momentum:

children.html: dL⃗dt=τ⃗ext\begin{align*} \frac{d\vec L}{dt} = \vec \tau_{ext} \end{align*}dtdL​=τext​​

children.value: where the angular momentum and torque are measured about the same axis or point of rotation, fixed in an inertial frame of reference.

The total angular momentum of a system about a point of rotation is conserved (i.e. does not change with time) if there is no net external torque exerted on the system about that point. If one makes the system large enough, then all of the torques can be taken to be internal, and the angular momentum of the system is conserved. The angular momentum of the Universe about a fixed point is thus conserved.

Conservation of angular momentum is another conservation law that we derived from Newton’s Second Law. In the modern formulation of physics, we understand that the conservation of angular momentum is associated with rotational symmetry of Newton’s Second Law; it does not matter from which

we model a system, we can always use Newton’s Second Law. Similarly, conservation of linear momentum is associated with translational symmetry and conservation of energy is associated with the fact that Newton’s Second Law does not change with time. Angular momentum is fundamentally different than linear momentum and energy, and is conserved under different conditions. The angular momentum of a system about a given axis/point is conserved if there is no net torque on the system about that axis/point.
\begin{example}{During a spin, a figure skater brings his arms close to his body and increases his angular velocity from

children.html: ω1\omega_1ω1​
ω2\omega_2ω2​

children.value:
. By what fraction did his moment of inertia decrease in doing so?}
We can consider the rotation axis to be vertical through the centre of the skater. When the figure skater is spinning, there is no net external torque on him. Thus, his angular momentum is conserved as he bring his arms in. As he bring his arms in, his moment of inertia decreases, since he is bringing the mass of his arms closer to the axis of rotation. If

children.html: I1I_1I1​
I2I_2I2​

children.value: are the moments of inertia of the skater before and after brining his arms in, respectively, we can write the angular momentum about his axis of rotation as:

children.html: L1=I1ω1L2=I2ω2\begin{align*} L_1 &= I_1\omega_1\\ L_2 &= I_2\omega_2 \end{align*}L1​L2​​=I1​ω1​=I2​ω2​​

children.value: Since there is no external torque on the skater, the angular momentum is the same before and after he changes his moment of inertia:

children.html: L1=L2I1ω1=I2ω2∴I1I2=ω2ω1\begin{align*} L_1 &= L_2\\ I_1\omega_1 &= I_2\omega_2\\ \therefore \frac{I_1}{I_2} &= \frac{\omega_2}{\omega_1} \end{align*}L1​I1​ω1​∴I2​I1​​​=L2​=I2​ω2​=ω1​ω2​​​

\begin{solution}{prob:angularmomentumrolling:balldisk}\label{soln:angularmomentumrolling:balldisk}
We consider the projectile and disk as a system, and a rotation axis that passes through the centre of disk. There are no external torques exerted on the system about the rotation axis, so the angular momentum of the system must be conserved through the collision. Before the collision, only the projectile has angular momentum about the axis of rotation, so the magnitude of the angular momentum before the collision is:

children.html: L=rpsin⁡ϕ\begin{align*} L = rp\sin\phi \end{align*}L=rpsinϕ​

children.value: is the angle between the particle’s momentum,

children.html: p⃗=mv⃗\vec p=m\vec vp​=mv
r⃗\vec rr

children.value: , from the axis of rotation to the particle. We can calculate the particle’s angular momentum just before the collision, so that

children.html: r⃗\vec rr

children.value: is the vector from the centre of the circle to the point where the particle collides (with magnitude

children.html: RRR
v⃗\vec vv

children.value: ). The initial angular momentum of the system is thus:

children.html: L=rp=Rmv\begin{align*} L=rp=Rmv \end{align*}L=rp=Rmv​

children.value: After the collision, the projectile is embedded in the disk. The resulting object has a moment of inertia given by:

children.html: I=Idisk+Iparticle=12MR2+mR2\begin{align*} I = I_{disk}+ I_{particle} = \frac{1}{2}MR^2+mR^2 \end{align*}I=Idisk​+Iparticle​=21​MR2+mR2​

children.value: After the collision, the angular momentum of the disk with the embedded projectile is given by:

children.html: L′=Iω=(12M+m)R2ω\begin{align*} L'=I\omega = \left(\frac{1}{2}M+m\right)R^2\omega \end{align*}L′=Iω=(21​M+m)R2ω​

children.value: Using conservation of angular momentum, the angular velocity of the disk after the collision is:

children.html: L=L′Rmv=(12M+m)R2ω∴ω=mv(12M+m)R\begin{align*} L &= L'\\ Rmv &= \left(\frac{1}{2}M+m\right)R^2\omega\\ \therefore \omega &= \frac{mv}{\left(\frac{1}{2}M+m\right)R} \end{align*}LRmv∴ω​=L′=(21​M+m)R2ω=(21​M+m)Rmv​​

children.value: We do not expect that mechanical energy is conserved during the collision, since the projectile embeds itself, which must cost energy. The mechanical energy before the collision is given by the kinetic energy of the projectile:

children.html: E=12mv2\begin{align*} E = \frac{1}{2}mv^2 \end{align*}E=21​mv2​

children.value: After the collision, the kinetic energy is the rotational kinetic energy of the disk with embedded projectile about the axis of rotation:

children.html: E′=12Iω2=12(12M+m)R2(mv(12M+m)R)2=12m2(12M+m)v2\begin{align*} E' &= \frac{1}{2}I\omega^2 = \frac{1}{2} \left(\frac{1}{2}M+m\right)R^2 \left( \frac{mv}{\left(\frac{1}{2}M+m\right)R}\right)^2\\ &= \frac{1}{2} \frac{m^2}{\left(\frac{1}{2}M+m\right)} v^2 \end{align*}E′​=21​Iω2=21​(21​M+m)R2((21​M+m)Rmv​)2=21​(21​M+m)m2​v2​
E′E'E′
EEE

E′E=12m2(12M+m)v212mv2=m(12M+m)<1\begin{align*} \frac{E'}{E} &= \frac{\frac{1}{2} \frac{m^2}{\left(\frac{1}{2}M+m\right)} v^2}{\frac{1}{2}mv^2}\\ &=\frac{m}{\left(\frac{1}{2}M+m\right)}<1 \end{align*}EE′​​=21​mv221​(21​M+m)m2​v2​=(21​M+m)m​<1​

children.value: and we confirm that mechanical energy is not conserved in the collision (and that energy was lost since one had to deform the projectile and disk).
Linear momentum is clearly not conserved since the final linear momentum is zero, whereas before the collision, it is

children.html: p⃗=mv⃗\vec p=m\vec vp​=mv

children.value: . The centre of mass of the disk+projectile system moves before the collision and not after. There must thus be a net external force that is exerted on the system. That force is exerted by the table onto the axle of disk, as the disk would otherwise recoil when hit with the projectile.

In this example, we used conservation of angular momentum to model a collision. The collision is inelastic, because the projectile embeds itself into the disk. The linear momentum is not conserved through the collision because the axle about which the disk rotates must exert a force on the disk to prevent it from recoiling.
\end{solution}
